sen.j: 大達 羽左エ門（おおだて うざえもん、嘉永6年12月15日 (旧暦)（1854年1月13日） - 明治37年（1904年）8月17日）は出羽国田川郡 (羽前国)（現・山形県鶴岡市）出身の力士で、最高位は大関。
sen.e: Uzaemon ODATE (January 13 1854 - August 17 1904) is a sumo wrestler who was born in Tagawa County, Dewa Province (present-day Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture) and his highest rank was ozeki (second highest rank in sumo).

Uzaemon ODATE (January 13 1854 - August 17 1904) was a sumo wrestler who was born in Tagawa County, Dewa Province (present-day Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture) and his highest rank was ozeki (second highest rank in sumo).

Uzaemon ODATE (January 13 1854 - August 17 1904) was a sumo wrestler who was born in Tagawa County, Dewa Province (present-day Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture) and his highest rank was ozeki (second highest rank in sumo).

sen.j: 本名は諏訪弁冶。
sen.e: His real name is Benji SUWA.
His real name is Benji SUWA.
His real name is Benji SUWA.

sen.j: 現役時代の体格は175cm、125kg。
sen.e: His height and weight during his playing days is 175cm and 125 kg.
His height and weight during his playing days were 175cm and 125kg.
His height and weight during his playing days were 175cm and 125kg.

sen.j: 養父は元前頭千賀ノ浦喜三郎。
sen.e: His foster father is Kisaburo CHIGANOURA, a former sumo wrestler who ranked maegshira (the rank of the makuuchi [senior-grade] division that is below the komusubi).
His foster father was Kisaburo CHIGANOURA, a former sumo wrestler who ranked maegshira (the rank of the makuuchi [senior-grade] division that is below the komusubi).
His foster father was Kisaburo CHIGANOURA, a former sumo wrestler who ranked maegshira (the rank of the makuuchi [senior-grade] division that is below the komusubi).

sen.j: 農家の次男に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born a farmer's second son.
He was born as the second son of a farmer.
He was born as the second son of a farmer.

sen.j: 若い頃から怪力で知られたが、大食漢なうえ大の相撲好きが災いして家業をおろそかにすることが多く、養子先から離縁され、本職の力士を目指して上京する。
sen.e: He was known as "Heracles" from his youth, but, in addition to great appetite, he quite often neglected his job because of being too passionate about sumo, and therefore the family that had adopted him dissolved the adoption, then he went to Tokyo to become a professional sumo wrestler.

He was known as "Heracles" from his youth, but, in addition to great appetite, he quite often neglected his job because of being too passionate about sumo, and therefore the family that had adopted him dissolved the adoption, then he went to Tokyo to become a professional sumo wrestler.

He was known as "Heracles" from his youth, but, in addition to great appetite, he quite often neglected his job because of being too passionate about sumo, and therefore the family that had adopted him dissolved the adoption, then he went to Tokyo to become a professional sumo wrestler.

sen.j: はじめ朝日嶽鶴之助のいる立田川 (相撲)部屋に入門し番付にも載るが、やがて脱走。
sen.e: At first, he joined Tatsutagawa stable which Tsurunosuke ASAHIDAKE belonged to, and he was ranked in banzuke but later escaped the stable.
At first, he joined Tatsutagawa stable which Tsurunosuke ASAHIDAKE belonged to, and he was ranked in banzuke (official ranking) but later escaped the stable.
At first, he joined Tatsutagawa stable which Tsurunosuke ASAHIDAKE belonged to, and he was ranked in banzuke (official ranking) but later escaped the stable.

sen.j: 新潟県を放浪、造り酒屋などで奉公しながら、素人相撲で活躍していたが、明治10年（1877年）高砂浦五郎_(初代)「高砂改正組」事件を率いて巡業に来ていた高砂浦五郎 (初代)に見出され、再入門する。
sen.e: He wandered around Niigata Prefecture and he served an apprenticeship in a sake brewer, but in 1877,while he showed his great performance in amateur sumo, his skill caught the attention of Uragoro TAKASAGO (the first) who were on regional tours (jyungyo) leading "Takasago kaiseigumi", and he joined his stable.

While wandering around Niigata Prefecture and serving apprenticeships in sake brewers, he showed his great performance in amateur sumo, in 1877, his skill caught the attention of Uragoro TAKASAGO (the first) who were on regional tours (jyungyo) leading "Takasago kaiseigumi", and ODATE joined the stable.
sen.cmt: 前半を整理して簡潔にしました。he → ODATE
sen.e: While wandering around Niigata Prefecture and serving apprenticeships in sake brewers, he showed his great performance in amateur sumo, in 1877, his skill caught the attention of Uragoro TAKASAGO (the first) who were on regional tours (jyungyo) leading "Takasago kaiseigumi", and ODATE joined the stable.

sen.j: 明治15年（1882年）6月場所新入幕。
sen.e: In 1882, he was promoted to makuuchi in June sumo tournament.
In 1882, he was promoted to makuuchi in June sumo tournament.
In 1882, he was promoted to makuuchi in June sumo tournament.

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）3月の天覧相撲では明治天皇の希望により横綱梅ヶ谷藤太郎 (初代)との割が組まれ、土俵中央で四つに組んで30分以上をしのぎあう大相撲の末、引分 (相撲)。
sen.e: In the tenranzumo (sumo wrestling performed in imperial presence) of March 1884, the bout between him and yokozuna Totaro UMEGATANI (the first) was arranged according to the request of Emperor Meiji, but the match ended in a draw after more than 30 minutes of stalemate with the two gripping each other's belt in the center of Dohyo (sumo ring).

In the tenranzumo (sumo wrestling performed in imperial presence) of March 1884, the bout between he and yokozuna Totaro UMEGATANI (the first) was arranged according to the request of Emperor Meiji, but the match ended in a draw after more than 30 minutes of stalemate with the two gripping each other's belt in the center of Dohyo (sumo ring).

In the tenranzumo (sumo wrestling performed in imperial presence) of March 1884, the bout between he and yokozuna Totaro UMEGATANI (the first) was arranged according to the request of Emperor Meiji, but the match ended in a draw after more than 30 minutes of stalemate with the two gripping each other's belt in the center of Dohyo (sumo ring).

sen.j: 天皇をおおいに喜ばせるとともに、この時代の東京相撲を代表する名勝負に名を残した。
sen.e: The Emperor was extremely rejoiced by the match and it became one of the greatest bouts representing Tokyo-zumo in this period.
The Emperor was extremely rejoiced by the match and it became one of the greatest bouts representing Tokyo-zumo in this period.
The Emperor was extremely rejoiced by the match and it became one of the greatest bouts representing Tokyo-zumo in this period.

sen.j: 続く5月の本場所では新小結。
sen.e: In the following official sumo tournament of May, he was promoted to komusubi.
In the following official sumo tournament of May, he was promoted to komusubi.
In the following official sumo tournament of May, he was promoted to komusubi.

sen.j: 明治14年（1881年）1月場所で58連勝が止まって以来再び35連勝を続けていた梅ヶ谷を破り、8勝0敗1分1休と現在でいう幕内優勝に相当する星をあげる。
sen.e: He defeated Umegatani who had 35 consecutive wins after the winning streak had ended at 58 in January sumo tournament in 1881, and he finally scored eight wins, no loss, one draw and one absent, which is equivalent of taking championship in the present day.

He defeated Umegatani who had 35 consecutive wins after the winning streak had ended at 58 in January sumo tournament in 1881, and he finally scored eight wins, no loss, one draw and one absent, which is equivalent of taking championship in the present day.

He defeated Umegatani who had 35 consecutive wins after the winning streak had ended at 58 in January sumo tournament in 1881, and he finally scored eight wins, no loss, one draw and one absent, which is equivalent of taking championship in the present day.

sen.j: 西の大関楯山久三郎がこの場所を最後に現役を退いたこともあって、当然大関昇進と当人も周囲も信じた。
sen.e: West ozeki Kyusaburo TATEYAMA retired making this tournament his final bouts, and, needless to say, ODATE and his surroundings believed his promotion to ozeki.
West ozeki Kyusaburo TATEYAMA retired making this tournament his final bouts, and, needless to say, ODATE and his surroundings believed his promotion to ozeki.
West ozeki Kyusaburo TATEYAMA retired making this tournament his final bouts, and, needless to say, ODATE and his surroundings believed his promotion to ozeki.

sen.j: しかし、翌場所では関脇で5勝だった西ノ海嘉治郎 (初代)が大関に、大達は三役格張出の位置に留め置かれた。
sen.e: However, while Kajiro NISHINOUMI (the first) who scored only five wins in the following tournament as sekiwake (a sumo wrestler of the third highest rank) was promoted to ozeki, ODATE was kept in the position of "sanyakukakuharidashi".

In the following tournament, however, while Kajiro NISHINOUMI (the first) who scored only five wins as sekiwake (a sumo wrestler of the third highest rank) was promoted to ozeki, ODATE was kept in the position of "sanyakukakuharidashi (deputy to three highest rank)".
sen.cmt: in the following tournamentの位置が間違っていると思います。先頭に移動させました。(deputy to three highest rank)を補足しました。
sen.e: In the following tournament, however, while Kajiro NISHINOUMI (the first) who scored only five wins as sekiwake (a sumo wrestler of the third highest rank) was promoted to ozeki, ODATE was kept in the position of "sanyakukakuharidashi (deputy to three highest rank)".

sen.j: この処遇に不満で、「いずれきっと上がれるのだから、今回は我慢しろ」となだめる師匠高砂と口論となり、激昂して手をあげてしまう。
sen.e: He complained about this decision and tried to raise his hand against his stable master TAKASAGO who appeased him saying that he should put up with it because he would be promoted soon.

He grew so infuriated about this decision that he quarreled with his stable master TAKASAGO who tried to appease him saying "you should put up with this because you would be promoted soon" and finally lifted a hand against him
sen.cmt: tried to raise his hand では意味がおかしいと思うので、再構成しました。
sen.e: He grew so infuriated about this decision that he quarreled with his stable master TAKASAGO who tried to appease him saying "you should put up with this because you would be promoted soon" and finally lifted a hand against him

sen.j: 怒った高砂からは破門を宣告され、以降伊勢ノ海（柏戸宗五郎 (5代)）のもとに身を寄せることになった。
sen.e: TAKASAGO who got angry expelled him and, after that, he moved to Isenoumi (Sogoro KASHIWADO (the fifth)).
TAKASAGO who got angry expelled him and, after that, he moved to Isenoumi (Sogoro KASHIWADO [the fifth]).
sen.cmt: カッコを整理しました。
sen.e: TAKASAGO who got angry expelled him and, after that, he moved to Isenoumi (Sogoro KASHIWADO [the fifth]).

sen.j: のちに正式に移籍する。
sen.e: Later, he officially transferred.
Later, he officially transferred.
Later, he officially transferred.

sen.j: 明治19年（1886年）1月場所新大関。
sen.e: He was promoted to ozeki in January sumo tournament in 1886.
He was promoted to ozeki in January sumo tournament in 1886.
He was promoted to ozeki in January sumo tournament in 1886.

sen.j: 当然横綱も期待され三つ揃いの廻し化粧廻しも用意されたが、酒量が過ぎたことから胃腸を患い、明治21年（1888年）1月場所から3場所全休、前頭に陥落する。
sen.e: As a matter of course, he was expected to become yokozuna and a three-piece keshomawashi (ornamental sumo apron) was prepared, but he suffered from bad stomach and intestines due to heavy drinking and it forced him to miss three consecutive tournaments from January 1888, and finally he was deposed to maegashira.

As a matter of course, he was expected to become yokozuna and a three-piece keshomawashi (ornamental sumo apron) was prepared, but he suffered from bad stomach and intestines due to heavy drinking and it forced him to miss three consecutive tournaments from January 1888, and finally he was demoted to maegashira.

As a matter of course, he was expected to become yokozuna and a three-piece keshomawashi (ornamental sumo apron) was prepared, but he suffered from bad stomach and intestines due to heavy drinking and it forced him to miss three consecutive tournaments from January 1888, and finally he was demoted to maegashira.

sen.j: 以降は勝ち越しも1度だけと苦難の土俵が続く。
sen.e: After that, he went through difficult times with experiencing only one tournament which he had more wins than losses.
After that, he went through difficult times with experiencing only one tournament which he had more wins than losses.
After that, he went through difficult times with experiencing only one tournament which he had more wins than losses.

sen.j: 明治28年（1895年）6月場所を最後に現役を引退。
sen.e: He retired after June sumo tournament in 1895.
He retired after June sumo tournament in 1895.
He retired after June sumo tournament in 1895.

sen.j: 年寄千賀ノ浦として弟子の育成に尽力したが、大きな成果は残せずに50歳で没。
sen.e: As toshiyori (a retired wrestler who is a trustee of the Japan Sumo) Chiganoura, he devoted himself to train apprentices, but without significant result, he died at 50.
As toshiyori (a retired wrestler who is a trustee of the Japan Sumo) Chiganoura, he devoted himself to train apprentices, but without significant result, he died at the age of 50.
sen.cmt: the age ofを補足しました。
sen.e: As toshiyori (a retired wrestler who is a trustee of the Japan Sumo) Chiganoura, he devoted himself to train apprentices, but without significant result, he died at the age of 50.

sen.j: 人情家で下のものの面倒見は良かった反面、小事に拘泥しない性格は周囲との関係をこじれさせることも多く、理解者に恵まれない土俵人生だったと評される。
sen.e: He was compassionate and cared his juniors well, but he often made relationship with others worth because of his character that is not to stick to small stuffs, and it is said that he was not blessed with others to understand him through his sumo life.

He was compassionate and cared his juniors well, but he often made relationship with others worse because of his character that is not to stick to small stuffs, and it is said that he was not blessed with others to understand him through his sumo life.

He was compassionate and cared his juniors well, but he often made relationship with others worse because of his character that is not to stick to small stuffs, and it is said that he was not blessed with others to understand him through his sumo life.

sen.j: 筋肉質な体躯で戯れにその腕を数人の好角家に噛ませてみたが、まったく歯がたたなかったという逸話が残る。
sen.e: There is an anecdote that he was so well-muscled that his arm was unharmed when he let several men who like sumo bite it just for pleasure.
There is an anecdote that he was so well-muscled that his arm was unharmed when he let several men who like sumo bite it just for pleasure.
There is an anecdote that he was so well-muscled that his arm was unharmed when he let several men who like sumo bite it just for pleasure.

sen.j: 生まれ持った怪力を活かした突き押し中心の相撲で、また徳利投げの荒業もあった。
sen.e: His sumo was characterized by tsuki (thrust) and oshi (push) making use of his innate physical strength and he also practiced the dynamic throwing technique called tokkurinage.
His sumo was characterized by tsuki (thrust) and oshi (push) making use of his innate physical strength and he also practiced the dynamic throwing technique called tokkurinage.
His sumo was characterized by tsuki (thrust) and oshi (push) making use of his innate physical strength and he also practiced the dynamic throwing technique called tokkurinage.

sen.j: 一方その立合いは、中腰で拳を相手の鼻先に突き出すもので、傍若無人の批判もあり、相手力士からも嫌がられた。
sen.e: In addition to that, his tachiai (initial stance at the beginning of sumo) was criticized as impudence because of the style to push his fist in a half-sitting posture toward his opponent, and the other sumo wrestlers also hated it.

In addition to that, his tachiai (initial stance at the beginning of sumo) was criticized as impudence because of the style to push his fist in a half-sitting posture toward his opponent, and the other sumo wrestlers also hated it.

In addition to that, his tachiai (initial stance at the beginning of sumo) was criticized as impudence because of the style to push his fist in a half-sitting posture toward his opponent, and the other sumo wrestlers also hated it.

sen.j: ある場所では、これを嫌った相手力士がとうとう暴発、大達の髷をつかんで土俵上に引き倒す騒動も起こっている（星取では両者休場の扱い）。
sen.e: In a tournament, an opponent sumo wrestler who hated it and finally exploded with rage grasped ODATE's mage (topknot) and drew him down on Dohyo (On the hoshitori (score sheet), the both wrestlers were treated as absence).

In a tournament, an opponent sumo wrestler who hated it finally exploded with rage and grasped ODATE's mage (topknot of wrestler's hair) and drew him down on Dohyo (sumo ring) (On the hoshitori [score sheet], the both wrestlers were treated as absence).
sen.cmt: andは不要と考えて削除しました。(topknot of wrestler's hair)と(sumo ring)を補足しました。カッコを整理しました。
sen.e: In a tournament, an opponent sumo wrestler who hated it finally exploded with rage and grasped ODATE's mage (topknot of wrestler's hair) and drew him down on Dohyo (sumo ring) (On the hoshitori [score sheet], the both wrestlers were treated as absence).

sen.j: 幕内通算26場所 87勝40敗21分3預109休 勝率.685
sen.e: In total 26 tournaments, 87 wins, 40 loses, 21 draws, 3 azukari (undecided) and 109 absences; winning percentage.685.
In total 26 tournaments, 87 wins, 40 loses, 21 draws, 3 azukari (undecided) and 109 absences; winning percentage.685.
